description.text: This image depicts the execution by hanging of Khudi Ram Bose (1889-1908) a freedom fighter from Bengal, under the British rule. Judges and a window with lattice can be seen in the background. The window shows a man and a guard in uniform inside the room. The text written in the image is written in Hindi (lines 2 and 3) and Bengali lines 1 and 4) Khudi Ram Phaansi (hanging), born, 3rd December 1889 and martyred, 12th August 1908

description-en: This image depicts the execution by hanging of Khudi Ram Bose (1889-1908) a freedom fighter from Bengal, under the British rule. Judges and a window with lattice can be seen in the background. The window shows a man and a guard in uniform inside the room. The text written in the image is written in Hindi (lines 2 and 3) and Bengali lines 1 and 4) Khudi Ram Phaansi (hanging), born, 3rd December 1889 and martyred, 12th August 1908 (sp)
explanatory comments/crosstagging: Quality issue: image poorly stitched / reassembled from multiple parts, seams are clearly visible in the eyes of the judge to the right. (ma)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Pinney (2004) writes extensively on the relationship of Gandhi versus Bhagat Singh and also mentions several images featuring Khudiram. He also mentions that chromolithographs circulated after his execution by the British in 1908, also underlining a fascination with modern/western technologies, such as telephones, watches, hanging technologies (ref to ills 86-88 in Photos of the Gods): "They provide a powerful sense of the resonances that colonialism's techno-rational grid had acquired by the early 1940s." (2004: 117). Most of the images show men looking at their watches as they wait for his execution, be they colonial administrators or, as in the case of this image, judges. See 117-128. (cb)
related literature: Pinney, Christopher. 2004. Photos of the Gods. Delhi: Oxford University Press
Pinney, Christopher. 2004. Photos of the Gods. Delhi: Oxford University Press
Quality issue: image poorly stitched / reassembled from multiple parts, seams are clearly visible in the eyes of the judge to the right.

Pinney (2004) writes extensively on the relationship of Gandhi versus Bhagat Singh and also mentions several images featuring Khudiram. He also mentions that chromolithographs circulated after his execution by the British in 1908, also underlining a fascination with modern/western technologies, such as telephones, watches, hanging technologies (ref to ills 86-88 in Photos of the Gods): "They provide a powerful sense of the resonances that colonialism's techno-rational grid had acquired by the early 1940s." (2004: 117). Most of the images show men looking at their watches as they wait for his execution, be they colonial administrators or, as in the case of this image, judges. See 117-128.
